Line: I'm a jinx. I went to your last wedding, and look how that turned out. Come on, Gaby. We both know it'd be weird if I went.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Okay, maybe a little, but it'll be weirder if you don't.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Excuse me?

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Look, everyone knows you're living with Edie. If she shows up alone, people will think I asked her not to bring you, like it bugs me that you guys are together.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: But it does bug you. You hit the roof when you found out.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Which is why I have to show people that I'm okay with it. Please, just consider it my wedding gift.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Okay, but I'm skipping the ceremony.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: What? And just go to the reception? You can't do that.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: I don't want to make a scene. You'll vow, till death do us part, I'll bust out laughing, people will stare…

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Reception starts at four.

Speaker: Susan
Line: I'm thinking a chocolate fountain would be a cool centerpiece to a dessert buffet.

Speaker: Mike
Line: Dessert buffet? We're having a wedding cake, right? Isn't that dessert?

Speaker: Susan
Line: Yeah, but you have to give people a choice. Don't you think a chocolate fountain would be elegant?

Speaker: Mike
Line: I don't know…you, a big white dress, melted chocolate. Am I the only one hearing alarm bells?

Speaker: Susan
Line: Fine, we'll skip the chocolate. How out a champagne fountain? Oh, I know! Maybe we can make the champagne flow through the ice sculpture.

Speaker: Mike
Line: Don't you think we might be going a little over-the-top?

Speaker: Susan
Line: Mike, these are all fairly standard wedding features. Now you name one thing that you think is going over-the-top.

Speaker: Mike
Line: How about the dove wrangler?

Speaker: Susan
Line: Well, the doves are not going to release themselves.

Speaker: Mike
Line: Do we really need forty of 'em?

Speaker: Susan
Line: Okay, I know that you think I'm being silly, but all of our friends went to Bree's wedding, and now they're going to Gaby's. Two months from now, do we really want them thinking our wasn't as nice?

Speaker: Mike
Line: It seems to me our friends wouldn't be there to make petty comparisons. They'd be there to celebrate our love.

Speaker: Susan
Line: You would think that, but no. Come on. This is something that we have both looked forward to for so long. Don't you want it to be perfect?

Speaker: Mike
Line: Oh, I guess. About the doves, though…

Speaker: Susan
Line: What?

Speaker: Mike
Line: You in a wedding gown, forty birds circling overhead? Again, not liking those odds.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Oh, it's not as bad as it sounds. It's, um, Hodgkin's Lymphoma, and apparently, if you're going to get lymphoma, that's the kind you want.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Hey, you wanna hold it down up there, kids? I'm trying to talk to your Aunt Lucy! Thank you!

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Anyway, I know I said that we would come and visit you this June, but I'll be a little woozy and…bald from the chemo, so…thanks for understanding. Oh, one more thing--our insurance policy has a really high deductible, so we are strapped financially, and I was wondering if maybe you and Dave might be able to…oh, really? No, I am not asking mom. She doesn't know about any of this, so don't you tell her, okay? We'll be fine. I love you. Bye.

Speaker: Tom
Line: I take it that's a no on the loan?

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Yep. Dave lost his job at the plant, and he is now handing out flyers at a chicken restaurant, and--prepare to wince-- there is a chicken suit involved.

Speaker: Tom
Line: Ouch.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: So where are we gonna find this ten thousand dollars?

Speaker: Tom
Line: You leave that to me. I want you to focus on getting better.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: But, honey--

Speaker: Tom
Line: I will find it. Meanwhile, we'll make some sacrifices around here. My tennis club membership is up this month. I'm not renewing.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Should you even be playing tennis after your back surgery?

Speaker: Tom
Line: Probably not.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Well, in that spirit, as soon as I start chemo, I will be giving up shampoo.

Speaker: Tom
Line: Okay, thanks.

Speaker: Orson
Line: Taxi's here. Are you sure you're ready to go back? We could wait another week.

Speaker: Bree
Line: And miss Gaby's wedding? No, I'll be fine.

Speaker: Orson
Line: Is, uh, this the dress you were thinking for the ceremony?

Speaker: Bree
Line: Yes.

Speaker: Orson
Line: Oh, good. I'll fold it in tissue so it doesn't wrinkle.

Speaker: Bree
Line: Oh, darling, I don't deserve you.

Speaker: Orson
Line: Oh, come on. We agreed--no more tears.

Speaker: Bree
Line: I'm so sorry to be putting you through this. I-I wouldn't blame you if you ran like hell and never looked back.

Speaker: Orson
Line: Stop. I'm going to raise this child and love it as if it were my own. Now let's see a smile.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Well, I'm glad you could join us, Milton. It's good to get to know you before the wedding.

Speaker: Milton
Line: Thank you. You know, I must say, all these months, I thought Victor was exaggerating about you. But he hasn't done you justice. You, my dear, are a flawless beauty.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: I'm hardly flawless. I'm sure I have a blemish hidden away somewhere.

Speaker: Milton
Line: Now that's a search I would relish.

Speaker: Victor
Line: She is way out of your league, dad.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Honey, he's a multimillionaire. He runs my league.

Speaker: Milton
Line: By the way, Victor, I, uh, ran into Keith Perkinson last week.

Speaker: Victor
Line: And how is the venerable state chairman?

Speaker: Milton
Line: Impressed with you. He liked the way you ran your moral campaign, said if you keep your numbers up, he might consider supporting you in the next governor's race.

Speaker: Victor
Line: Really?

Speaker: Victor
Line: What's so funny?

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: You gotta be kidding, right? I mean, we just finished a campaign. You're not about to put me through another one.

Speaker: Victor
Line: But I thought you loved campaigning.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: God, no. It's a complete snore. Pasting a smile on my face while you say the same speech for the fiftieth time?

Speaker: Victor
Line: But you were a natural. People loved you.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Well, the feeling wasn't mutual. You think I enjoyed sipping tea with these frumpy matrons who wore loud, polyblend pantsuits? You know how many times I just wanted to scream, "vote for my husband, you color-blind cow!"?"

Speaker: Milton
Line: I think you've discovered something very important about democracy, my dear--the nation is full of fools, and everyone gets a vote.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Well, they're not gonna get us again. I made nice with Fairview. I'm not about to suck up to the whole damn state.

Speaker: Susan
Line: What are you doing?

Speaker: Mike
Line: Some guy out in Mount Pleasant's got a cracked water heater.

Speaker: Susan
Line: It's three o'clock in the morning.

Speaker: Mike
Line: Well, I started advertising as a twenty-four-hour plumber. After midnight, I get triple time.

Speaker: Susan
Line: Okay, well, that's crazy. You can't work round the clock. It's not healthy.

Speaker: Mike
Line: Well, this is the third night I've worked this week. I'm fine so far.

Speaker: Susan
Line: You've been sneaking out while I've been asleep? What are you, ninja plumber?

Speaker: Mike
Line: It's just for a little while, earn some extra money.

Speaker: Susan
Line: Is this about the wedding?

Speaker: Mike
Line: We agreed we want it to be nice.

Speaker: Susan
Line: But we didn't agree on this. Maybe I can scale things back a bit.

Speaker: Mike
Line: How? Have a ginger ale fountain? Make paper doves and hope it's windy?

Speaker: Susan
Line: Okay, seriously, you don't have to kill yourself. I could max out my credit card.

Speaker: Mike
Line: Is that really how you want to start our life together--in debt?

Speaker: Susan
Line: No, I wanna start out happy. But clearly, you're upset, and I don't know why.

Speaker: Mike
Line: I'm not Ian. I can't afford to move you into a mansion or fly you off to Paris, but I'll be damned if I don't give you the same dream wedding he would have given you. I'll see you in the morning.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Where the hell do you get off having cancer and not telling me about it?!

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Mom…

Speaker: Stella
Line: How do you think you could handle this without me?

Speaker: Tom
Line: Stella?

Speaker: Stella
Line: Oh, there's my Tommy boy! Come here!

Speaker: Stella
Line: Oh! God. Oh, listen, be a love, will you, honey, and get my bags from the cab?

Speaker: Tom
Line: Bags? She's staying?

Speaker: Stella
Line: Yep. And do not tip the driver. SOB wouldn't let me smoke.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Jeez, Lynette, I didn't know you opened a day care center. Hey, kids, grandma's here.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Okay, what did you tell them about me?

Speaker: Lynette
Line: It's been five years, mom. They don't remember you.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Well, they'll remember me this time. I brought presents.

Speaker: Kids
Line: Cool!

Speaker: Stella
Line: Hey…for you, and…you, and you.

Speaker: Parker
Line: These are baby toys. We're too old to play with these.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Well, I'm too old to remember what the hell six-year-olds like to play with.

Speaker: Twin
Line: We're eight.

Speaker: Stella
Line: What do I care?

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Just say thank you.

Speaker: Kids
Line: Thank you.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Oh, who's the pretty thing? Your girlfriend?

Speaker: Parker
Line: No! She's my sister!

Speaker: Stella
Line: Oh. Is that Tom's little b-a-s-t-a--

Speaker: Tom
Line: Okay, kids, time to get your toys and let's play upstairs. Come on, Penny. Come on, sweetie. Let's go, everybody.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Listen, mom, I really appreciate you coming to help, but as you can see, I'm perfectly fine.

Speaker: Stella
Line: For now. Now how you gonna handle that mob when you're flat on your ass from chemo?

Speaker: Lynette
Line: I'll manage. You got through breast cancer while raising the three of us alone.

Speaker: Stella
Line: I was not alone. I had you.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Lynette was all of thirteen, and she still looked after her sisters, cleaned the house, cooked the meals, and I was curled up in a ball, puking my guts out.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Well, that's what you get when you mix chemo and vodka gimlets.

Speaker: Stella
Line: You can goad me all you like, Lynette. I did not come here to fight. Now trust me, cookie, I have memorized the whole catalog of subjects you and I can no longer discuss, and if that means that we have to talk about the weather for three months, then fine. But I am staying. Now…if you'll excuse me, I have to go kick a child out of its room.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Okay. Legs up!

Speaker: Edie
Line: Oh, you wanna do it again?

Speaker: Carlos
Line: No. I've been doing a lot of research, and gravity helps facilitate the sperm reaching the eggs. So…heave-ho!

Speaker: Edie
Line: Oh! Well, could we try a little light spooning before you hang me up like a side of beef?

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Edie, we're trying to have a baby.

Speaker: Edie
Line: Well, could we be a little less clinical? Maybe let nature take its course?

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Nature is not on our side anymore. Look, you're no spring chicken, and those eggs aren't exactly farm-fresh.

Speaker: Edie
Line: Okay, stop referring to me as poultry.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Sorry. Can we just try this? It's only for thirty minutes.

Speaker: Edie
Line: Thirty minutes?! I am not staying in this position for a half an hour.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Listen, I know that this requires some work, but it will all be worth it when we have our beautiful, beautiful baby. Right?

Speaker: Edie
Line: Right. I guess I could…make some sacrifices.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: That's my girl. Can I get you anything?

Speaker: Edie
Line: Yeah. I'd kill for a beer.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Sorry. No alcohol.

Speaker: Edie
Line: What? For how long?

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Just until the baby's born. Oh, and you stop nursing. Don't worry. I'll get you a nice herbal tea.

Speaker: Tom
Line: It's just for a few months while you're in treatment. We're--we're gonna have to find someone to watch the kids.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: No! I am not leaving that woman in charge of our children. In three months, the twins will be chain-smoking, and Penny will be an alcoholic. We can manage. We've got McCluskey.

Speaker: Tom
Line: She costs money--money that we won't have if we're paying someone to replace you at work.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: You said not to worry about money, that you'd find it somewhere.

Speaker: Tom
Line: I did.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: What, someone loaned us ten thousand dollars?

Speaker: Tom
Line: No, gave us, and we can't thank her by kicking her out.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: No! Tom, you didn't ask my mother?!

Speaker: Tom
Line: Didn't have to. She knew that you hit up Lucy, so she offered.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Well, we're giving it back.

Speaker: Tom
Line: No, we can't afford to.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Tom, you don't know half the stuff she did to us. She would get drunk and smack us around. She would meet some new guy and then drop us off at her sister's for a week because he wasn't into kids.

Speaker: Tom
Line: Okay, so she was a crappy mom. You said yourself that she has mellowed. Now she wants to make amends.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: If you would just try to understand…

Speaker: Tom
Line: I think that I've been pretty understanding lately.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: What's that supposed to mean?

Speaker: Tom
Line: I think you know.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Great, so in the middle of everything I'm dealing with, you're gonna throw Rick in my face.

Speaker: Tom
Line: When someone we love hurts us, if we still love them, we deal with it and we move on. If I can do it, so can you.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: So forgiving my mother…that's my penance?

Speaker: Tom
Line: Yeah. I think it is.

Speaker: Victor
Line: I thought you said we weren't supposed to spend the night before the wedding together.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Yeah, I was trying to respect tradition…but I got horny.

Speaker: Victor
Line: Well, I guess we'll just have to start the honeymoon early, won't we? Let me get rid of this stuff.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: What are you working on so late?

Speaker: Victor
Line: Nothing.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Polling data? Why are you polling? The election's over.

Speaker: Victor
Line: It's just a little research. God, you look hot.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Is this about running for governor? Because I told you how I feel about that.

Speaker: Victor
Line: My dad just set up a little…exploratory committee. It's no big deal.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Oh. Okay, well, let's explore it now. Nope, not gonna happen.

Speaker: Victor
Line: Gaby--

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Victor, ever since we met, it's been photo ops and fund-raisers, and I'm sick of it.

Speaker: Victor
Line: Well, I'm a politician. Do you think I want my career to begin and end in the suburbs?

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Fairview is my home, and I don't want to leave it. And you can't make this decision without me. I'm gonna be your wife.

Speaker: Victor
Line: Exactly, not my career adviser.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Oh, so I don't even get a vote?

Speaker: Victor
Line: Not if it's a veto.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Okay, look, no! I already married a man who put his career before me, and I swore I wasn't gonna do it again.

Speaker: Victor
Line: Well, I swore I would not let a stupid woman hold me back.

Speaker: Victor
Line: That did not come out the way I wanted it to. I'm sorry. I'm sor--I'm really sorry. I've just been under a lot of pressure lately.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Well, here's one less thing you have to worry about-- our wedding.

Speaker: Victor
Line: You can't cancel the wedding. It's too late.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: As far as I'm concerned, it's just in the nick of time.

Speaker: Milton
Line: Good morning, Gaby.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: God, Milton, the newspaper's not even here yet.

Speaker: Milton
Line: I'm sorry it's so early. I just…came to apologize.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Why? What happened wasn't your fault.

Speaker: Milton
Line: That's not exactly the case. Is that coffee I smell?

Speaker: Milton
Line: You only bolted because Victor wants to be governor. He only wants to be governor because of me.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: You only suggested it. You can't make him go after something he doesn't want.

Speaker: Milton
Line: The hell I can't. Ever since he was a kid, Victor's been killing himself trying to live upto his big shot father. He's desperate for my approval.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Why?

Speaker: Milton
Line: I suppose because he's never gotten it. Everything he does--even becoming mayor-- I somehow let him know that it's not quite enough. Oh…don't get me wrong. I'm right to push. That's why he's so successful.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: So what are you saying, I should marry Victor because you're a withholding father?

Speaker: Milton
Line: No, I just want you to understand why he does what he does.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Fine. I get it. But why would I want a husband who values his father's opinion more than mine?

Speaker: Milton
Line: Well, he doesn't really care much what I think anymore. After you left last night, he called me and, uh…what's the phrase? Tore me a new one?

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: He did?

Speaker: Milton
Line: He said because of me, he'd lost the best thing that had ever happened to him, and if he couldn't win you back, I could take my money and buy a new son, because I was never gonna be hearing from him again.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: He blew off eighty million dollars? Well, if he cares about me so damn much, why am I not hearing this from him?

Speaker: Milton
Line: I think you're about to.

Speaker: Milton
Line: Is there a back way out of here?

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Aren't you gonna be late for Gaby's wedding?

Speaker: Edie
Line: Oh, weddings are boring. I like to sneak in at the end, look teary-eyed and pretend I was there the whole time. I am gonna see you at the reception.

Speaker: Edie
Line: Oh! Uh, hi, Danny. Um…Carlos, the paperboy's here. Could you pay him? Come on in.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Hey, here you go, Danny. Oh. Uh, looks like I'm a little short. Can I catch you later?

Speaker: Danny
Line: No.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Okay. Hold on.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Oh, my god.

Speaker: Danny
Line: What's that?

Speaker: Carlos
Line: It's birth control pills.

Speaker: Danny
Line: I'm gonna need cash.

Speaker: Andrew
Line: Hey, welcome home!

Speaker: Bree
Line: I have missed you, sweetheart!

Speaker: Andrew
Line: Oh, here, allow me.

Speaker: Bree
Line: Well, hello there, Julie.

Speaker: Julie
Line: You guys are back!

Speaker: Bree
Line: Wow, somebody's…blonder.

Speaker: Julie
Line: Oh, yeah, my mom hates it, too. So where's Danielle?

Speaker: Bree
Line: Well, um, while we were in Switzerland, she ran across this boarding school, and she fell in love with it and just insisted that we let her spend a year abroad.

Speaker: Julie
Line: Wow. She must be having a really good time. She hasn't returned any of my phone calls.

Speaker: Andrew
Line: Oh, well, um, you know, her school's up in the mountains, and--and her cell phone reception is kind of funky.

Speaker: Julie
Line: She hasn't answered my e-mails, either.

Speaker: Bree
Line: Well, I am gonna call her tonight and have a little talk with her about common courtesy, and I'm sure that you will get an e-mail first thing tomorrow morning. Well, we should go. I've got to get that bracelet to Gaby before the wedding.

Speaker: Julie
Line: Well, I'll see you guys there. Bye.

Speaker: Orson
Line: Well, that was uncomfortable.

Speaker: Andrew
Line: You have no idea. Everyone's been asking questions.

Speaker: Bree
Line: This might not be as easy as we'd hoped.

Speaker: Bree
Line: There. Now you have something new.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: So how do I look?

Speaker: Lynette
Line: You are now officially the most beautiful bride that ever lived.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Until your wedding, of course.

Speaker: Susan
Line: Nice save.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: It means so much to me that we're all here together right now.

Speaker: Susan
Line: And…break!

Speaker: Reverend
Line: We are gathered here today to join together Victor Lang and Gabrielle Marquez in matrimony--an honorable estate not to be entered in lightly, but reverently and soberly. This is a lifetime union-- one based on love, honor and trust…

Speaker: Edie
Line: You wanna be my new best friend? Premium scotch. Keep it coming.

Speaker: Reverend
Line: You are promising not only to give of yourself, but also to accept each other, promising not only to love for today, but to extend that love to include…

Speaker: Edie
Line: Carlos! I thought you weren't coming until after--

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Save it…

Speaker: Edie
Line: Okay, look, I can explain--

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Don't bother! Your lies were more convincing when I cared.

Speaker: Reverend
Line: Victor, do you take Gabrielle…

Speaker: Edie
Line: Carlos! You've got to understand. I do wanna have a baby with you, just not yet. I…I just--I wanted to give you a chance to fall in love with me first.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: I don't believe you, and I will never trust you again!

Speaker: Edie
Line: Well, what was I supposed to do? You backed me into a corner, and you were gonna bail on us, and I was just trying to save what we had. Carlos, don't leave me…please just talk to me.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: I am done with you.

Speaker: Edie
Line: Carlos!…

Speaker: Reverend
Line: Ladies and gentlemen, I present to you Mr. and Mrs. Victor Lang.

Speaker: Edie
Line: …I'm sorry!

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Mrs. McCluskey! Enjoy the wedding?

Speaker: Mrs. McCluskey
Line: Nice. Very classy. Although what the hell was that brouhaha between Carlos and Edie?

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: I don't know and I don't care. Today, I'm so filled with love, I can forgive anyone anything. Oh, um, but if you do see them again, call security.

Speaker: Bree
Line: So we're in Zurich, and I was sick after breakfast for the third morning in a row. And I thought to myself, dear god, I hope I have not developed an allergy to chocolate brioche. Life just wouldn't be worth living.

Speaker: Orson
Line: So I said, that's it. We're seeing a doctor. Well, you could've knocked us over with a feather when he said she was already two months pregnant.

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Aw, I think it's so great, and we could not be happier for you. When's your due date?

Speaker: Bree
Line: Oh, not until the early fall, but enough about me. This is your day--you and Victor--who, by the way, I have not met yet.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Oh, my gosh, that's right. Okay, you stay here. I'm gonna go grab him.

Speaker: Bree
Line: It is so good to be back. I can't believe how much is happening. I mean, you and Gaby getting married, and I'm having a baby. What's going on with you, Lynette?

Speaker: Lynette
Line: Nothing. Same old, same old.

Speaker: Susan
Line: Really? Is everything okay, sweetie? 'Cause you haven't quite seemed yourself the last couple weeks."

Speaker: Lynette
Line: I'm fine. Everything's just fine.

Speaker: Victor
Line: I'll tell you this much--I'm exhausted. I'll be glad when this day is over.

Speaker: Milton
Line: Well, it was all worth it. Marrying Gaby is the smartest thing you've ever done. With her bringing in the Latino vote, the governor's mansion's as good as yours.

Speaker: Victor
Line: Well, that's assuming I can change her mind. I had to make certain concessions just to get her down the aisle.

Speaker: Milton
Line: You're the husband now. The rules have changed. Be nice, buy her a few pretty things. Trust me, you'll be able to tame that little spitfire.

Speaker: Victor
Line: I'm not too worried. I've always been able to manage my assets.

Speaker: Bree
Line: Did you find him?

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: No, I'm still looking, but I'll let you know.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Oh, movie's over. And may I add…amen. Go out and play. Go on, go on. Out!

Speaker: Kayla
Line: They're just gonna go play guns. Can I watch another movie?

Speaker: Stella
Line: Oh, Lynette said one was the limit, and she'll be home soon.

Speaker: Kayla
Line: No, she won't. Whenever they go out to a party, they always come home at least an hour later than they say they will.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Aren't you an observant little monkey? Tell me, sweetie…would you know anything about a man named Rick?

Speaker: Kayla
Line: Yeah, I know Rick. My daddy and Lynette had a big fight about him.

Speaker: Stella
Line: Really? Sounds like there's maybe a little story there.

Speaker: Kayla
Line: If I tell you, could I watch a really good grown-up movie?

Speaker: Stella
Line: If it's a really good grown-up story.

Speaker: Susan
Line: Okay, I got you some appetizers to tide you over. We have mini quiches and beef satay and something called Crystal Coast shrimp with grits, but it's mostly just grits 'cause I ate all the shrimp on my way over. Mike?

Speaker: Susan
Line: Reverend, that was such a beautiful ceremony. Really, just heartfelt and moving--the whole package.

Speaker: Reverend
Line: Why, thank you.

Speaker: Susan
Line: Yeah, it was really impressive. So what are you doing tonight?

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Oh, Carlos. Didn't know you were in here.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: I got a little thirsty.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: Yes. I can see that.

Speaker: Carlos
Line: Gaby, I am sorry if I ruined your wedding. But if it's any consolation, I also ruined my life.

Speaker: Gabrielle
Line: What are you talking about?

Speaker: Carlos
Line: A couple years ago, I was totally happy. I had a home, you, a great career. And I don't understand how I let it all go to hell. And now here I am, back at square one. I really blew it. Ah, what am I doing? I shouldn't be dumping this on you. It's your wedding day. Go to Victor. I'm gonna stay right here--

Speaker: Lynette
